LEAD: The Economy
The Economy

Energy efficiency has stopped growing, ending a trend dating from the energy crisis of the early 1970's, U.S. statistics show. The shift means greater dependence on foreign oil, which is near an all-time high, and makes the U.S. more vulnerable to oil shortages and price increases. The change also bodes ill for efforts to limit smog, acid rain and the ''greenhouse effect.'' [ Page A1. ]
Machine-tool orders dropped 27.1 percent in December, an industry group reported. Analysts said the decline resulted from seasonal weakness and lower orders from abroad. [ D1. ]
Steel industry employment rose 6.2 percent last year, after nearly a decade of declines, as producers try to meet higher demand. But industry employment remains far below its peak. [ D1. ]

President Bush can reshape Federal securities regulation as he fills openings on the Securities and Exchange Commission. His choices are likely to be more favorable to regulation than were S.E.C. members of the Reagan years. [ D2. ] Companies

Liz Claiborne's founders said they would retire in June from active management roles in the clothing company. Elisabeth Claiborne Ortenberg and her husband, Arthur, will remain on the company's board. Jerome A. Chazen will become chairman and Henry L. Falk will be vice chairman and president. [ D1. ]
Higher-performance computers will be introduced this week, giving a push to chip designs by Intel and Motorola. [ D1. ]
The National Mediation Board has urged President Bush to appoint a panel to look into a labor dispute at Eastern Airlines. [ D2. ] International Report

The Philippine economy has grown in each of the three years since Corazon C. Aquino became President. Despite questions about how strong the recovery has been and how long it can be sustained, the mood is optimistic. [ D1. ]
H. J. Heinz remains the only major U.S. company in Zimbabwe seven years after it began its profitable investment. [ D4. ]
Taiwan is on a buying spree, and U.S. cars are high on the shopping list. The Big Three enjoyed record sales there last year. [ D4. ] The Media Business
National Public Radio is ''on a roll,'' its president says, after repaying its debt and ending 1988 with a $7.8 million surplus. [ D13. ]

Will publishers and bookstores avoid controversial works, like the novel by Salman Rushdie, in the face of future threats? Despite pledges that there will be no concessions, some critics say the industry has left itself open to threats. Reporter's Notebook. [ D13. ]
State lotteries have begun to compete with game shows. In Michigan, contestants on a popular show are selected from among ticket buyers and treated as celebrities. [ D13. ]
CBS appears set to overtake ABC in the prime-time ratings, evidence of the power of a runaway hit series. Television. [ D13. ]
The International Team has become a fixture at McCann-Erickson, successfully promoting American products to affluent audiences around the world. Advertising. [ D14. ]
The New York Post starts a Sunday issue next weekend. [ D13. ] Today's Columns

Short-term rates may move higher in the next week or so, even without further tightening of credit by the Fed. People in the markets say current rates do not fully reflect last week's half-point rise in the Federal funds rate. Credit Markets. [ D7. ]
The dismantling of an effort to corner Chase Medical's stock is about to begin. After more than six weeks it is still unclear who will end up controlling most of the shares. Market Place. [ D6. ]
New York's new method of calculating the income tax owed by residents of other states is unlikely to raise their tax bills dramatically. Several states already use the method. Tax Watch. [ D2. ]
